title: Quiz 5: Management of HIV/AIDS (ART & VCT)
topicName: Unit Six: STIs and HIV AIDS
description: Examine the pharmacological management of HIV using ARVs and the importance of Voluntary Counselling and Testing.

questions.question: What is the main goal of Antiretroviral Therapy (ART)?

options.text: To suppress viral load and preserve immune function
To replace the need for condoms

questions.explanation: There is no cure. ART aims to suppress the virus, improve quality of life, and reduce morbidity/mortality.

questions.question: Match the ARV Drug Class with its mechanism of action:

pairs.right: Incorporates into DNA to stop building process
Binds directly to reverse transcriptase enzyme
Prevents successful assembly and release of virus

questions.explanation: Nucleoside analogues act as false building blocks. NNRTIs block the enzyme. Protease inhibitors stop the final assembly.
questions.hint: Protease inhibitors work at the 'last stage'.

questions.question: Select the drugs that belong to the 'Nucleoside Analogue' class: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Zidovudine, Lamivudine, and Stavudine are Nucleoside Analogues. Efavirenz is an NNRTI. Indinavir is a Protease Inhibitor.
questions.hint: Look for drugs often ending in -dine or -ine (but check the specific list).

questions.question: The acronym HAART stands for ___BLANK___ Active Anti-Retroviral Therapy.
Knowing one's HIV status through VCT has been shown to drastically change sexual behavior.
questions.explanation: Research shows that knowing one's status empowers people to make informed decisions and adopt safer sex practices.

questions.question: What is the laboratory marker used to determine the strength of one's immune system before starting ART?
questions.explanation: The CD4 cell count is the marker used to assess immune system strength.

questions.question: Which of the following is a risk of DELAYED antiretroviral therapy?
questions.explanation: Delaying treatment risks the immune system becoming too weak to recover (irreversible depletion). Early resistance is a risk of *early* therapy.
questions.hint: If you wait too long, what happens to the immune system?

questions.question: Who benefits from VCT services? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: VCT benefits everyone, including those planning futures (marriage/pregnancy) and those at high risk.
questions.hint: It's not just for the sick.

questions.question: Order the HIV testing process when results are equivocal (borderline):
questions.explanation: If the first two are positive but the third is negative, it is equivocal. The protocol requires re-testing after 2 weeks.
questions.hint: What happens if the tie-breaker test is negative?

questions.question: Review the table of Protease Inhibitors. Which drug is listed as a combination?
questions.explanation: Lopinavir + Ritonavir is the combination listed.
